comments.commentBody: Get back to us in a few years when your kids are bored to death watching lectures on screen at Cal State.  Unless of course you've left California by then because you've been replaced by a computer and a team of academic drudges in India.

I'm cheering too because my children are in junior high and are sure to benefit from this revolution in education. My father was an advisor at the local university and 25 years ago, he would advise students away from degrees that would put them in the pickle so many California students are in, desperately waiting for course availability. He also pushed for credit for life learning, knowing that a college degree was a ticket to success for people from a variety of backgrounds, including older and foreign students.
With community colleges overcrowded, online colleges charging exorbitant rates despite being unaccredited, and our local U's quality of ed having taken a nosedive because they're desperate to take any student who qualifies for loans, I'm more than ready for a revolution.
My son, who has a learning disability, thrives on online learning and is highly disciplined and motivated. His school resists having him do even one course online, which would allow him a Khan-style flipped approach that he finds enormously superior to the "listen to lecture, instantly regurgitate material on worksheet" approach they use for everything, including science (no money for labs) and math (no option for nonconstructivist curricula). He can start taking online courses after high school, including the 2 yrs. foreign language he can't take in school because they don't offer Latin and he doesn't have room in his schedule.
I'm doing a happy dance!

I'm a UC Davis faculty member with children in high school.
All I can say is YAY!

That is unlikely because the Google Street View mapping is handled by a third party contractor.  The driver is given a route and simply drives the route.  At the end of the day the collected images (and other things) are dumped back to a Google data collection facility.

Google Glass. Hmmm. Seems to me Robert A. Heinlein wrote about senior citizens recording and simultaneously transmitting video from spectacles called "creepie peepies".

Does that mean all video footage shot by news crews and live TV shows constitute invasions of privacy?

I doubt that. But collecting home network passwords is another matter. Not nice.
That's not what the case was about. You have no expectation of privacy for what's in public view. I could stand on the sidewalk and take the same picture.

What are the damages? Unless your personal passwords appear listed on Google info page, there are no damages to photograph your residents from the public domain i.e. street. If Google is selling photos of your home, then you have rights to a settlement. Otherwise, what damages?

Mike: Yes, Sal IS right, but he didn't say what you seem to think he said. He said "we ought to divert those DEFENSE [my emphasis] funds", not "we ought to divert NASA funds". NASA's discoveries have had and will continue to have a clear bearing on how to keep or make Earth habitable. It can't be done without perspective.

Doubtful it'll be our relatives.  Our window of having an advanced technological civilization is rapidly closing. We are already seeing the argument play out - anemic budgets for science, no functional space program, no attempts at colonization on anything, and just burying ourselves in atmospheric change elements.  When do you think our future generations will reach for the stars?  When they're struggling against crippling drought to raise enough crops to eat?  Or scratching ever deeper to find the dirtiest of fossil fuels as the waves lap further inland and fresh water becomes more precious than oil?  No, my friend, I am fearful that humanity has signed its own warrant for decline - signed in oil and writ on money.
hmmm someday some species or even our relatives might look back in time from space at the earth and say the same thing about us - food for thought

Habitable for whom? Oh, of course -- us. Sad to think the first thing we want to do with Mars is make it another Earth.

We should do everything possible to prevent contaminating Mars even with our microbes. How about using all that "defense" money to clean up our air and water, help the poor, support medical research, foster humane treatment of animals and otherwise reduce suffering of sentient beings here on Earth?

Re: " 'That 'God' chose Earth?' Presently it's as valid as 'there is other life in the universe.' "

'Fraid not. There may or may not be "other" life in the universe, but at least the question has real meaning and the possibility of a definitive answer. The question of whether God chose Earth is utterly meaningless and can never be answered. It's not worth the millisecond it takes a rational being to dismiss.

Does that mean you support the present Apartheid state Israel?
The USA did long support Aparheid South Africa (it was anti-communist!).
By doing so now in the Mid-East, the USA play away, like senseless child, more sympathy and willingness to cooperate than ever.
When Palestinians continue to elect Terrorist to lead them, they make the bed and must sleep in it.

Look to history. If the conflict was one of the need for a Palestinian state why did Jordan & Egypt not create one while they had control of Gaza and the West Bank from 1948 to 1967? Why did the people of Arab Palestine not accept the UN partition plan of 1947 but instead either were encouraged to leave by the surrounding Arab states or by coercion by the victorious Israelis? The current conflict is not a de novo situation but a cumulative result of years of deadlock from both sides but recall the Arab dicta of eliminating Israel.It is difficult to negotiate with those whose final offer is disappear or die.

"Finally, while America’s need to forge Israeli-Palestinian peace has never been lower, the obstacles have never been higher: Israel has now implanted 300,000 settlers in the West Bank, and the Hamas rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza have seriously eroded the appetite of the Israeli silent majority to withdraw from the West Bank, since one puny rocket alone from there could close Israel’s international airport in Lod."

The rockets are what President Obama should ask President Mahmoud Abbas about. When it comes to this issue, the silent majority is probably the absolute majority.

Israel is as gridlocked as America is right now. Even if Netanyahu had some secret long-term peace plan, there is no way he could keep together the coalition he is building, as we speak, were he to put it forward publicly. The same would be true had Labor had won enough votes to be putting together a coalition of its own. Israeli politics are polarized as ours are and, ironically, may remain so for another year or more, until new elections are called. It seems America and Israel are in similar boats.

Insurance covers 90 percent of his salary while he is DL'd.  IF he comes back and plays (but doesn't ala last season) the Yanks are on the hook. HOWEVER- Hank made this deal after Arod opted out. Perhaps Hal should have Hank reimburse the team with all his Murdoch cash!

The GOP did not win the election but they do control the House and 30 state governors are Republican as compared to 19 Democrats.  We have not come to one party Democratic rule, at least not yet.   Both parties need to compromise.
I think it has been shown, and the Iraq war is a perfect case in point, that the American public with its 15 minute memory span will believe anything if it is said loudly and often enough.

The ignorant elected Obama, nothing to be proud of , Mr. Underwood.  The fact that liberals have failed to note this fact and actually think they are smarter would be amusing, if it was not so pathetic.  In reality, Mr. Obama has reinstated himself with a bunch of self-sanctified, back slapping bleeding-heart liberals who have no idea what their policies will do to America's future!  The GOP may well be in need of an update, no question, but ignorant people voting for a man ONLY based on his skin color is pathetic and dangerous!  Interview after interview of a wide group of people on the street shows they have no idea what Obama's  policies are and cannot accurately tell you WHY they elected him!  These people have wronged America, and they have no idea what they have done and evidently, neither do you!   Ryan is trying to save America and her jobs and her economy through a logical, intelligent  procedure of not spending more than we make.  Obama is seeking to weaken America through bloated government and irresponsible spending!  The  Socialistic /Communistic policies of Obama are grossly flawed and history has proven repeatedly they do not work!  They are in direct conflict with a productive FREE economy!  This will result in an America none of us will recognize in 10 years if allowed to continue unchecked!  Support Mr. Ryan, a man who actually loves America and is intelligently trying to save it!  IGNORANCE IS NOT BLISS!

It would appear they Mr. Ryan (I use the Mr. loosely) seems to think the GOP won the election.

There seems to be something psychologically impaired about Ryan. The GOP leadership seems to believe that if they keep repeating the same propaganda often enough more people will believe them.

The current membership in the GOP is ossified. But then when you consider education in liberal arts like philosophy, history, rhetoric and other arts that require critical thinking, as a waste of time, this is what you get. And they have developed a following with the same defects.

Yes, it was an enjoyable, witty theme, but my, wasn't this a gritty little entry for a Wednesday—at least for me. I started off by putting in so much plausible but incorrect fill that if it had been a weekender I would have been in thrall to Mlle Check and still probably have had a DNF. ASIA Minor (23A), CONVOY (25A), TILT (35A), LEGEND (47A), FIE (5D), PATS (26D), RING BEARER (28D), and GLOP (51D) were all well placed to mess up many attempts at cross words. I finally had to give it a very thorough redo to get to MHP. No complaints, though. Fair and fun.

"Many of us will be watching Jeter's climb up the all-time hit list. [A]s exciting as yet another winning season if not more so."

"As exciting" as winning? "If not more so?"

What?

I don't think Mr. Jeter would agree with that.

You must not be a Yankee fan. Because, for Yankees fans, we cannot win enough World Series.

I think you are really a Mets fan, either in denial or unaware of it. Perhaps you should think about coming out of the closet.

In one of the NY rags today, Hal was quoted as saying, he didn't know what 200 mil bought being that they only had one WS title in the last 5 years.  Hal, it's Branding!  your father is rolling in his grave watching you boys kill his BRAND!  Sell the team already!  You split up 2 Bil from Murdoch, tho he is handing over another 350,000 a year for what?  The next 25-30 years?  Count your money and have fun in Tampa, but sell the team to someone who cares.  It's not you.  There was a reason your dad kept you boys out of the family business until he was barely there.

3 f35s could be purchased.... the cost per plane has increased to $137million....

i'd say a couple of quite profitable boondoggles in this collection...
We buy DRONES now haven't you heard,, but I would suspect we could buy enough to protect your sorry rear..
1.7 planes (unless the cost goes up next year ;-)
How many outdated and ineffective fighter planes could we have bought with all that money?

The troops in Afghanistan, questioning Mr. Hagel, the new Secretary of Defense on his first visit since taking on his new job, was a reminder of the one in charge...the Commander in Chief, President Obama.

The insecruity of millions of Americans back home, looking into the future, has now infiltrated the minds of our troops, even as they fight for their lives in a foreign land...the insecruity of coming home to a country, not knowing what to expect.

President Obama, the Commander in Chief, has failed those that he commands. The questions Hagel was asked by our troops, were of a nature of concern...retirement and jobs...when they return home. There is reason of concern, knowing that many of their peers before them, were refused, staying in the military, looking forward to retirement, by the Obama administration.

While President Obama will not cut expenditures from overlapping social programs, loaded with corruption and deceit, he will deprive those that have spent many years in the military, a job, staying in the military.

A President that has his priorities grossly misplaced...that has weaken a once strong confident nation, to one that is asking questions...even from our troops in combat.

If all unimplemented/unfinished crimes were fantasies, 911 was a big fantasy until 3000 people were killed. After all, the killers' coming to the US was legal, attending pilot school was legal, so was their air travel. There is a crime called "conspiracy".

I think people are confused. He was convicted of conspiracy to kidnap/murder based on his plans and actions (rope,surveillance, computer use). Not for his thoughts alone, and not for his actions alone.

I'm skeptical. Another interpretation of his actions (sketchy as they are) is that like all fantasies, his are more fun when they're detailed. He hunts an action woman, at a real house, using the rope he just bought. Weird, absolutely. But consider the prosecutions interpretation:

An apparently upstanding, well respected and mentally sound/nonviolent (according to the psychiatrist) police officer is about to go kill and eat women. Why? Because he lusts for female flesh. I find this hard to believe. Means and motive he has, but that motivation is pretty out there.

People with kinds certainly overstep the law and good taste in pursuit of their jollies (Anthony Weiner, peeping Toms, etc). And Valle should be punished for his actual infractions. But how many of the BDSM community are actually abusive in real life? How many of us fantasize about becoming astronauts with the expectation that it'll really happen?

I think it's more likely Valle is a man with a weird kink who went too far in filling in the details. But it's a huge leap from inappropriate computer use to actually killing and eating someone.

(A text book conspiracy would be a man negotiating with hitmen to take out his dad for the inheritance. A bit different from Valle, eh?)
Yes when his wife found out about his detailed plan of eating her, she wouldn't be scared if things like Aurora hadn't happened ...

I have a feeling "concerned citizen" from "Anywheresville" is actually a 'corporate citizen' located in Atlanta. I hope the Bloomberg administration tightens up the statute and prevails in all of this. I cant imagine cheering some one lugging 32, even 64 Oz.'s of sugar water around... Indefensible.
"Concerned Citizen" is a corporate interest.

I'm not sure that you know what you're talking about. My triple by-pass heart surgery probably cost a lot more than any taxes I paid while smoking cigarettes. I'm due to have surgery to alleviate the blockage in the arteries in my legs and my neck. The doctors all tell me that my circulatory problems are due to my smoking cigarettes for 43 years. Smoke 'em if ya got 'em!!!
Daniel Dennett?

If n exhaustive knowledge of all pertinent physical laws doesn't result in knowledge of what it's like to experience colours (or anything else), then materialism is refuted.  This brain having to be in a certain physical state is a transparent red herring.

If there is knowledge that cannot in principle be expressed via information eg a book, then it cannot be knowledge which is quantifiable (since if it were quantifiable then it would be able to be expressed).

Your point about the brain not being in an appropriate state etc is to go off on a tangent and not get to grips with the thought experiment.

Re Zombie: You cannot presuppose the truth of reductive materialism to reject this thought experiment! A p-zombie is conceivable, so you need to address the question of why therefore it is not metaphysically possible. You cannot brush off the problem by presupposing your own position. It's called question begging.

This is what passes for philosophy?

Before Mary sees the red flowers, her brain has encoded all the physical laws governing the perception of color. However, this information is encoded, e.g., symbolically in her brain. Although her brain has encoded descriptions of the physical changes that occur in our brains when we see color, her brain has not gone through these changes itself. There's no contradiction in this state of affairs -- her brain encodes the math and physics of color differently than it encodes color itself. When she finally does see red, her brain undergoes the changes she's leaned about. Nothing non-physical about it.

Your argument is analogous to saying that, just because I can't experience sound from reading a book, there must be something extra-physical about sound. No! Some experience that can be encoded by our physical brains just can't be encoded in a black-and-white book. It's still physical experience, though.

The zombie example is so stupid it doesn't deserve a response, but here goes. The core problem is that it pre-supposes that there is an extra-physical component to experience, and then uses that assumption to prove itself. By declaring that a zombie could be in the exact same physical state as myself yet lack my experiences, you are already supposing an extra-physical aspect to experience. If there is no extra-physical aspect, then the whole premise is invalid.

There is a large overlap between these groups and rate of medicaid use.

BTW, your arguments about why should taxes pay for your heart attack, supports the notion that in fact it shouldn't.

Or to put it another way, you are arguing for Paul Ryan's vision of healthcare, which frankly, may be the sanest course: let people do as they see fit, but also experience the outcomes without forcing others to cushion the blow.

I'm a major fiscal conservative and I continue to see what obesity is doing to our population. Ironically, the poorest eat the fattiest, the saltiest and the sweetest fast food. We pay hundreds of Billions for Hemo-dialysis, strokes, heart attacks, wheel chairs and nursing homes for these very people who have paid next to nothing in social security and Medicare, yet demand that I keep their stroked-out, on-dialysis, fed-through-a feeding-tube, on-a-ventilator, nearly-brain-dead  family member in the ICU and "do everything".
Who said anything about a ban? I believe the issue is a tax on unhealthy products.

I'm a left-wing vegetarian, but I have to agree with the conservatives and libertarians who call this law a noxious nanny-state nostrum.
If the government can ban large sodas on the grounds of public health, what's to stop it from banning red meat? (Why should my taxes pay for your heart attack, some of the commenters here would argue.)
What's to stop it from limiting the number of drinks someone can have in a bar? (Why should my taxes pay for your cirrhosis?)
What's to stop it from making gym membership compulsory? (Why should my taxes pay for people who are too lazy to keep in decent physical shape?)

There are some things that are not right but should not be illegal.

Also, I find it ironic that Bloomberg's so fanatical about this. Wasn't he the one who wanted to put Snapple sweet-tea vending machines into city schools?
